body.head: Bibliography
body.p: Applegarth, Risa. Rhetoric in American Anthropology: Gender, Genre, and Science. University of Pittsburgh Press, 2014.
Banks, Ann, Leonard Rapport, and Federal Writers’ Project, eds. First-Person America. 1st ed. New York: Knopf : distributed by Random House, 1980.
Bawarshi, Anis. “Genre and the Invention of the Writer.” Logan: Utah State UP, 2003.
Bazerman, Charles, and others. Shaping Written Knowledge: The Genre and Activity of the Experimental Article in Science. Vol. 356, University of Wisconsin Press Madison, 1988.
Berry, Jason. “Up From the Soul.” My New Orleans (blog), April 1, 2014. https://www.myneworleans.com/up-from-the-soul/.

Blumer, Herbert. An Appraisal of Thomas and Znaniecki’s The Polish Peasant in Europe and America.
Judith Giving and Account of One Self, Fordham University Press, 2005.
Carmody, Todd. “Sterling Brown and the Dialect of New Deal Optimism.” Callaloo, vol. 33, no. 3, 2010, pp. 820–840.
Clopper, Cynthia G., and Ellen Dossey. “Phonetic Convergence and Divergence in the American Midwest.” The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America 145, no. 3 (2019): 1930–1931.
Coe, Richard M. “An Arousing and Fulfillment of Desires’: The Rhetoric of Genre in the Process Era—and beyond.” Genre and the New Rhetoric, 1994, pp. 181–190.
Coles, Robert Doing Documentary Work (New York Public Library, 1998).
Cooper, Marilyn M. “The Ecology of Writing.” College English, vol. 48, no. 4, JSTOR, 1986, pp. 364–75.
Couch, William Terry, ed. These Are Our Lives. University of North Carolina Press, 1939.

Dimock, Wai-Chee. Through Other Continents: American Literature across Deep Time. Princeton University Press, 2006.
Dubois, Sylvie, and Barbara M. Horvath. “Sounding Cajun: The Rhetorical Use of Dialect in Speech and Writing.” American Speech 77, no. 3 (2002): 264–87.

Enoch, Jessica. Domestic Occupations: Spatial Rhetorics and Women’s Work. SIU Press, 2019.

Finnegan, Cara. “Picturing Poverty.” Washington, DC: Smithsonian, 2003.
French, Scot A. “What Is Social Memory?” Southern Cultures, vol. 2, no. 1, 1995, pp. 9–18.
Foucault, Michel. The Archaeology of Knowledge & The Discourse on Language. Reprint. Vintage, 1982.
Fox, Daniel M. “The Achievement of the Federal Writers’ Project.” American Quarterly, vol. 13, no. 1, 1961, pp. 3–19.
Gold, David, and Jessica Enoch. Women at Work: Rhetorics of Gender and Labor. University of Pittsburgh Press, 2019.
Gold, David, and Catherine L. Hobbs. Educating the New Southern Woman: Speech, Writing, and Race at the Public Women’s Colleges, 1884-1945. SIU Press, 2013.
Goodey, Jo. “Biographical Lessons for Criminology.” Theoretical Criminology 4, no. 4 (2000): 473–98.

Graban, Tarez Samra. “Ripple Effects: Toward a Topos of Deployment for Feminist Historiography in Rhetoric and Composition.” In Networking Humanities: From Within and Without the University, edited by Jeff Rice and Brian McNely. Anderson, SC: Parlor Press, 2018.
Gross, Andrew S. “The American Guide Series: Patriotism as Brand-Name Identification.” Arizona Quarterly: A Journal of American Literature, Culture, and Theory, vol. 62, no. 1, 2006, pp. 85–111.
Hale, Grace Elizabeth. Making Whiteness: The Culture of Segregation in the South, 1890-1940. Vintage, 2010.

Harris, Bernice. Southern Savory. University of North Carolina Press, 1964.
Hecht, Tobias, After Life: An Ethnographic Novel, Duke University Press, 2006.
Hill, Lynda M. “Ex-Slave Narratives: The WPA Federal Writers’ Project Reappraised.” Oral History, vol. 26, no. 1, 1998, pp. 64–72.
Hirsch, Jerrold. Portrait of America: A Cultural History of the Federal Writers’ Project: A Cultural History of the Federal Writers’ Project. Univ of North Carolina Press, 2003.
Huyssen, Andreas. “Present Pasts: Media, Politics, Amnesia.” Public Culture 12, no. 1 (2000): 21–38.
Jackson, Rachel C. “Locating Oklahoma: Critical Regionalism and Transrhetorical Analysis in the Composition Classroom.” College Composition and Communication, JSTOR, 2014, pp. 301–26.
Jocher, Katharine. “The Case Method in Social Research.” Social Forces, 1928, 203–11.
Jockers, Matthew. Macroanalysis. University of Illinois, 2013.
Johnson, Jessica Marie. “Markup Bodies Black [Life] Studies and Slavery [Death] Studies at the Digital Crossroads.” Social Text 36, no. 4 (137) (2018): 57–79.

Moody-Turner, Shirley. Black Folklore and the Politics of Racial Representation. Jackson, MS: University Press of Mississippi, 2013.
Morris, Charles E. “The Archival Turn in Rhetorical Studies; Or, the Archive’s Rhetorical (Re) Turn.” Rhetoric & Public Affairs 9, no. 1 (2006): 113–115.
Morris III, Charles E., and K. J. Rawson. “Queer Archives/Archival Queers.” Theorizing Histories of Rhetoric, 2013, 74–89.

Nichols, Bill. Representing Reality: Issues and Concepts in Documentary. Indiana Press University, 1992.
O’Connor, Alice. Poverty Knowledge: Social Science, Social Policy, and the Poor in Twentieth-Century US History. Vol. 59. Princeton University Press, 2009.
Odum, Howard Washington, and Katharine Jocher. “An Introduction to Social Research.,” 1929.
Penkower, Monty Noam. The Federal Writers’ Project ; a Study in Government Patronage of the Arts. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1977.
Posner, Miriam. “Humanities Data: A Necessary Contradiction – Miriam Posner’s Blog.” Accessed October 16, 2019. https://miriamposner.com/blog/humanities-data-a-necessary-contradiction/.
Preston, Dennis R. “The Li’l Abner Syndrome: Written Representations of Speech.” American Speech 60, no. 4 (1985): 328–36.
Rabinowitz, Paula. They Must Be Represented: The Politics of Documentary. Verso, 1994.
Rapport, Leonard. “How Valid Are the Federal Writers’ Project Life Stories: An Iconoclast among the True Believers.” The Oral History Review, vol. 7, 1979, pp. 6–17.
Rawson, K.J. Archiving Transgender: Affects, Logic, and the Power of Queer History. Syracuse University, 2010. http://gradworks.umi.com.libproxy.lib.unc.edu/34/29/3429041.html.
Redding, Joan. “The Dillard Project: The Black Unit of the Louisiana Writers’ Project.” Louisiana History, 1991, 47–62.
Retman, Sonnet H. Real Folks: Race and Genre in the Great Depression. Duke University Press, 2011.
Renov, Michael, editor. Theorizing Documentary. Routledge, 1993.
Ritchie, Donald A. “Oral History in the Federal Government.” The Journal of American History, vol. 74, no. 2, 1987, pp. 587–595.
Rodgers, Lawrence R., and Jerrold Hirsch. America’s Folklorist: BA Botkin and AmericanCulture. University of Oklahoma Press, 2014.
Ross, Dorothy. The Origins of American Social Science. Vol. 19. Cambridge University Press, 1992.
Rowell, Charles H., and Sterling Allen Brown. “‘Let Me Be Wid Ole Jazzbo’: An Interview with Sterling A. Brown.” Callaloo, vol. 21, no. 4, Johns Hopkins University Press, 1998, pp. 789–809.
Rutkowski, Sara. Literary Legacies of the Federal Writers’ Project: Voices of the Depression in the American Postwar Era. Springer, 2017.
Sanders, Wiley B. “Recent Contributions in the Field of Juvenile Delinquency, Child Welfare, and Family Case Work.” Social Forces 6, no. 4 (1928): 648–53.
Shaw, Clifford R., and E. W. Burgess. The Jack-Roller: A Delinquent Boy’s Own Story. Chicago (Ill.): Martino Fine Books, 2013.

Shepley, Nathan. “Rhetorical-Ecological Links in Composition History | Enculturation.” Enculturation: A Journal of Rhetoric, Writing, and Culture, Feb. 2013, http://enculturation.net/rhetorical-ecological-links.
Smith, Mark C. Social Science in the Crucible: The American Debate over Objectivity and Purpose, 1918-1941. Duke University Press, 1994.
Smith-Rosenberg, Carroll. Disorderly Conduct: Visions of Gender in Victorian America. Reprint
edition. New York, NY: Oxford University Press, 1987.
Soapes, Thomas F. “The Federal Writers’ Project Slave Interviews: Useful Data or Misleading Source.” The Oral History Review, vol. 5, 1977, pp. 33–3
Stanley, Liz. “On Auto/Biography in Sociology.” Sociology 27, no. 1 (1993): 41–52.
Stewart, Catherine A. Long Past Slavery: Representing Race in the Federal Writers’ Project. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press, 2016.
Stewart, Kathleen, A Space on the Side of the Road, (Princeton University Press, 1996).
Stott, William. Documentary Expression and Thirties America. University of Chicago Press, 1973.
Tausig, Robert I Swear I Saw This: Drawings in Fieldwork Notebooks, Namely My Own (University of Chicago Press, 2011).

Terrill, Tom E., and Jerrold Hirsch. “Replies to Leonard Rapport’s ‘How Valid Are the Federal Writers’ Project Life Stories: An Iconoclast among the True Believers.’” The Oral History Review, vol. 8, 1980, pp. 81–89.
Terrill, Tom E., and Jerrold Hirsch, editors. Such as Us: Southern Voices of the Thirties. University of North Carolina Press, 1978.
Underwood, Ted. Distant Horizons: Digital Evidence and Literary Change. University of Chicago Press, 2019.

VanHaitsma, Pamela. “Between Archival Absence and Information Abundance: Reconstructing Sallie Holley’s Abolitionist Rhetoric through Digital Surrogates and Metadata.” Quarterly Journal of Speech, vol. 106, no. 1, Routledge, 2020, pp. 25–47.
Walpole, Jane Raymond. “Eye Dialect in Fictional Dialogue.” College Composition and
Communication 25, no. 2 (1974): 191–96.

Wexler, Laura. Tender Violence: Domestic Visions in an Age of US Imperialism. UNC Press Books, 2000.

White, Richard. “What Is Spatial History.” Spatial History Lab: Working Paper [Online] Http://Www. Stanford. Edu/Group/Spatialhistory/Cgi-Bin/Site/Pub. Php, 2010. https://web.stanford.edu/group/spatialhistory/media/images/publication/what%20is%20spatial%20history%20pub%20020110.pdf.
Wright, Earl. “W.E.B. Du Bois, Howard W. Odum and the Sociological Ghetto.” Sociological Spectrum 34, no. 5 (2014): 453–68.
